intro: Halophila ovata, commonly known as the Atlantic halophyte, is a marine flowering plant belonging to the Alismataceae family. It is a submerged aquatic plant that thrives in shallow, coastal waters and estuaries, often found in brackish environments. The plant has narrow, ribbon-like leaves and produces small, white flowers that are typically pollinated by water currents. Halophila ovata plays a crucial role in stabilizing sediment and providing habitat for various marine organisms. Its ability to tolerate varying salinity levels makes it an important component of coastal ecosystems.
